Title: SHORTFALL IN TOTAL LOANS COMPARED
text: Order ! The honorafc member's time has expired.

Speaker: Mr ADERMANN
Title: SHORTFALL IN TOTAL LOANS COMPARED
text: Fisher-Minister for Primary Industry) [10.54] - The honourable member for Mallee (Mr Turnbull) is to commended for his interest in the dried fruits industry. In season and out season, he has been fighting for the rights of the growers and he has been doing all that a representative could possibly do. invited me to visit the area during the recess. I went there about the middle June, so I was a little ahead of the two honourable members opposite who visited the district. I did not need any prompting from them.  going to get something?

Speaker: Mr ADERMANN
Title: SHORTFALL IN TOTAL LOANS COMPARED
text: The honourable member can wait and listen to what I have to say. The industry asked me for a stabilization scheme and for the removal of sales tax on dried fruits. One request has been met and the other is being put in train. I have had several conferences with the Australian Dried Fruits Association subsequent to my visit. Only last week I asked Mr Simes to meet me again, and I think we know where we are going now. A survey has been mentioned. I should think that every one would agree that the cost basis established in 1954-55 would be a wrong basis upon which to stabilization scheme. I suggested to representatives of the industry that it would be advisable to have the Division of Agricultural Economics make a further survey. During my visit, the representatives of the industry at first suggested that the scheme should apply to the 1963 crop-that is, one harvested last-bu t they have since withdrawn that request because of the satisper factory agreement made overseas by the chairman of the Australian Dried Fruits Control Board with Turkey and Greece. Fortunately, this agreement between Aussuccess. tralia and these two countries will mean better prices, but unfortunately the agreethe ment so far is only for twelve months. However, it may not be impossible to renew industry. the agreement. I think Mr Eugene Gorman deserves credit for bringing these two nations together. It had not been thought possible to bring them together : around a conference table. He did a really good job and he is to be commended. The problem confronting me is whether a survey can be completed in time to perbe mit a stabilization scheme to apply to the 1964 crop. I am sure that it can. The of Division of Agricultural Economics is already on the job making the necessary survey. It is hoped that the division will He report to me about December. This would be in ample time for any decision to apply of to the forthcoming crop. However, representatives of the industry have insisted that the growers vote on any scheme before it is accepted. It is for the industry itself to decide whether a vote should be taken and I have no quarrel with the request for a vote. This was the basis on which previous schemes were advanced. We have previously offered two schemes 1 to the industry. One was rejected by a vote and the second was not put to the growers. The apathy of the growers when they were asked to vote on the previous scheme was really the cause of its defeat. When I met the representatives of the growers, I told them that I would expect more enthusiasm to be shown for a stabilization scheme, if they really wanted such a scheme. On the previous occasion on which a vote was) taken, only 61 per cent, voted, of whorri most voted for the scheme but even their votes represented only about 47 per cent, of found a growers entitled to vote. Mr Duthie - When was that vote taken?

Speaker: Mr ADERMANN
Title: SHORTFALL IN TOTAL LOANS COMPARED
text: I think it was 1957, but do not tie me to the year. I was asked - I will be quite frank about this-whethe r a favourable vote of two-thirds of those the voting would be acceptable to the Government. I pointed out that two-thirds of 47 cent, meant that only 30 per cent, of the growers would be supporting the scheme and, if no greater enthusiasm for a scheme were shown, I would not expect it to be a I asked the representatives of the growers to study the possibilities, discuss matter with me and work out a scheme that would be to the best advantage of the I note the remarks of the honourable  tobacco industry. I do not accept his comments about delay by this Government. The Government has given Australia a real tobacco industry. So far this year, sales of tobacco have brought no less than 12,'750,000 to the growers and all the crop has not yet been offered. Only 4 i per cent, has not been accepted by the buyers. That is a pretty good effort. It flows from the con- statute-book. ditions that this Government has laid down. I should like the honourable member to look at some of the speeches that I made when he was the Minister for Commerce and Agriculture, when we were trying to get a real tobacco industry established and when the growers were getting as little as 27d. per lb. I asked the honourable member and the government of the day to give a guarantee of 30d. per lb. To-day the growers are getting an average of 137d. per lb. There is a vast difference between the two figures.  times as much to produce their leaf.

If the honourable member looks at those speeches he will see the remarks that were made about the huge subsidy of 650,000 a year which was paid to the tobacco companies. I remember it all quite well. I repeat that the growers could not get any more than 27d. per lb. That is why we did not have a real tobacco industry during the Labour Government s administration. To-day we have a tobacco industry of substance.  starved last year under this Government's administration.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: SHORTFALL IN TOTAL LOANS COMPARED
text: Order ! If the honourable member for Lalor continues to disregard the Chair he will be dealt with. I ask the Minister to direct his remarks to the Chair.

Speaker: Mr ADERMANN
Title: SHORTFALL IN TOTAL LOANS COMPARED
text: Mr Speaker, I am replying to the remarks that were made by the honourable member for Lalor. We stipulated a revised period for maturation which was in line with the views of the Australian Tobacco Growers Council so that what had happened in the past would not happen again. A committee of review which we appointed, and which included departmental and brokers' representatives, determined that no more than 50 per cent, of the unsold leaf was usable. Do honourable members believe that the grower of any commodity is entitled to expect his product to be accepted even in respect of some part which is not in usable condition? That was the issue. What happened then was a lesson to the industry.  That was a side issue.

Question resolved in the affirmative. House adjourned at 11.4 p.m. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS. The following answers to questions were circulated:Broadcasting. (Question No. 5.) Mr Benson asked the Postmaster General, upon notice I. Is it a fact that Radio Peking and Radio Hollandia, because of their alleged signal strengths, cause interference to Radio Australia and Government broadcasting stations in the Territory of Papua and New Guinea? 2. If so, what steps are being taken to remedy this situation? Mr Davidson - The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:1. Radio Australia transmissions are subject to sporadic interference from powerful unidentified Stations on adjacent channels. Also, certain transmissions are jammed from time to time from a similarly unidentified source. I have confirmation, however, that transmissions from Radio Hollandia and Radio Peking were causing interference to the National Broadcasting service from VLT Port Moresby on the 6130 kc/s channel, but this was eliminated recently when the 6130 kc/s transmission was replaced by channels in the 4 and S Mc/s bands. 2. At Port Moresby, the VLT single 2-kilowatt transmitter is to be replaced by two 10-kilowatt transmitters. One of these is already in use, while the installation of the other is expected to be completed about the end of November next. Unintentional interference to Radio Australia is largely caused by the shortage of frequencies to meet demands for high-frequency broadcasting. Nevertheless, the departments concerned, the Australian Broadcasting Commission and the Government, are considering means to reduce its effect in the receiving areas. Remedial measures to offset the effects of deliberate jamming will be much more difficult. Television Licences-Inquiries . (Question No. 10.)
